Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with pneumonia. Due to decreased SpO2, oxygen therapy was initiated. The condition improved with antibiotic treatment, oxygen was discontinued, and the patient was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

HasOxygenTherapy.evidence: Due to decreased SpO2, oxygen therapy was initiated.

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with acute bronchitis. Prominent cough and sputum were noted, and imaging showed no clear findings of pneumonia. Treatment focused on symptomatic management, including inhalation therapy and antitussives, resulting in improvement. Oxygen therapy was not required. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with high fever and dyspnea. SpO2 was 89%, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics for pneumonia, showed improvement, was weaned from oxygen, and discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with viral pneumonia. Due to decreased SpO2 on admission, oxygen therapy was initiated. The condition improved with antiviral agents and supportive care, and the patient was discharged after discontinuation of oxygen. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with dyspnea. SpO2 was in the low 90% range, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The patient was treated with antibiotics for pneumonia, showed improvement, was weaned from oxygen, and discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted for evaluation of hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy was performed to investigate the cause. Mild hypoxemia was noted, and oxygen therapy was administered; however, the clinical course was not primarily consistent with infectious pneumonia. The patient remained stable after the examination and was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with pneumonia. SpO2 was 91%, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The condition improved with antibiotic treatment, oxygen was gradually tapered and discontinued, and the patient was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted for surgical management of a femoral neck fracture. No findings suggestive of respiratory infection were observed, and no treatment for pneumonia was required. Oxygen therapy was not administered. The postoperative course was stable, and the patient was discharged after rehabilitation. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with pneumonia accompanied by dyspnea. SpO2 was 89–91%, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The condition improved with intravenous antibiotics, oxygen was discontinued, and the patient was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with acute gastroenteritis. Intravenous fluids were administered for dehydration caused by diarrhea and vomiting. Respiratory symptoms were minimal, and antibiotic treatment for pneumonia was not required. Oxygen therapy was not administered. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with fever and shortness of breath. SpO2 was 90–92%, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics for pneumonia, showed improvement, was weaned from oxygen, and discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with pharyngitis. The main symptoms were sore throat and fever, and chest imaging did not suggest pneumonia. The condition improved with oral antibiotics. Oxygen therapy was not required. ICU admission was not required.

HasAntibioticsPO.evidence: The condition improved with oral antibiotics.

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with pneumonia accompanied by dyspnea. Due to decreased SpO2 on admission, oxygen therapy was initiated. The condition improved with antibiotic treatment, oxygen was discontinued, and the patient was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with suspected interstitial pneumonia, presenting with dyspnea and decreased SpO2. Oxygen therapy was administered. The condition showed improvement with corticosteroid therapy, and antibiotics for infectious pneumonia were not the primary treatment. ICU admission was not required.

HasSteroidSystemic.evidence: The condition showed improvement with corticosteroid therapy

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with pneumonia. SpO2 was 91%, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The condition improved with intravenous antibiotics, oxygen was discontinued, and the patient was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with acute kidney injury. Dehydration was suspected, and intravenous fluids were administered. Respiratory symptoms and findings suggestive of pneumonia were minimal. Oxygen therapy was not required. The general condition improved, and the patient was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

HasAKI.evidence: The patient was admitted with acute kidney injury.

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with pneumonia accompanied by dyspnea. SpO2 was approximately 90%, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The condition improved with intravenous antibiotics, oxygen was discontinued, and the patient was discharged. ICU admission was not required.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with fever and cough. On admission, SpO2 was 96% on room air, and dyspnea was mild. Chest CT revealed an infiltrate in the right lower lobe, and community-acquired pneumonia was diagnosed. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated. Respiratory status remained stable on room air, and oxygen therapy was not required. The patient had a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus; glycemic control was maintained with oral hypoglycemic agents during hospitalization, with generally stable blood glucose levels. After improvement of inflammatory markers, antibiotics were switched to oral therapy, and the patient was discharged.

HasDiabetes.evidence: The patient had a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus

HasInsulinUse.evidence: glycemic control was maintained with oral hypoglycemic agents

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with cough and fever. SpO2 was 95% on room air, and the general condition was stable. Chest X-ray revealed an infiltrate in the left lower lung field, and intravenous antibiotics were initiated for community-acquired pneumonia. Respiratory status remained good during hospitalization, and oxygen therapy was not required. The patient had a history of diabetes mellitus; glycemic control was managed with diet therapy and oral medications. After symptom improvement, antibiotics were switched to oral therapy, and the patient was discharged home.

HasDiabetes.evidence: The patient had a history of diabetes mellitus

HasInsulinUse.evidence: glycemic control was managed with diet therapy and oral medications

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with dyspnea and fever. On admission, SpO2 was 91%, and oxygen therapy at 1 L/min via nasal cannula was initiated. Chest CT showed bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, and intravenous antibiotics were started for community-acquired pneumonia. Respiratory status improved, and oxygen was gradually tapered and discontinued. The patient had a history of diabetes mellitus; glycemic control was maintained with oral medications and dietary adjustment without initiation of insulin. After confirmation of overall clinical improvement, the patient was discharged.

HasOxygenTherapy.evidence: oxygen therapy at 1 L/min via nasal cannula was initiated

HasDiabetes.evidence: The patient had a history of diabetes mellitus

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with high fever and shortness of breath. SpO2 was 90–91%, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics for pneumonia, and respiratory status improved in parallel with a decrease in inflammatory markers, allowing discontinuation of oxygen. The patient had comorbid diabetes mellitus; blood glucose was controlled with oral agents, and insulin was not required. The course was favorable, and the patient was discharged home.

HasDiabetes.evidence: The patient had comorbid diabetes mellitus

HasAntibioticsIV.evidence: The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics for pneumonia

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with fever and cough. On admission, SpO2 was 97% on room air. Chest X-ray showed an infiltrate in the right lower lung field, and intravenous antibiotics were initiated for community-acquired pneumonia. Respiratory status remained stable, and oxygen therapy was not required. After symptom improvement, antibiotics were switched to oral therapy, and the patient was discharged.

HasAntibioticsPO.evidence: antibiotics were switched to oral therapy

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with severe pneumonia. On admission, SpO2 was 85% on room air, and high-flow oxygen therapy was initiated, followed by NPPV. The patient received ICU-level management with antibiotic therapy and respiratory support. After improvement in overall condition, the patient was transferred to the general ward. Following weaning from oxygen, the patient was discharged (transferred) for ongoing care.

[Hospital Course] The patient presented with fever, cough, and sputum production and was admitted. SpO2 on admission was 94–96% on room air, and oxygen therapy was not required. Chest CT revealed an infiltrate in the right lower lobe, and treatment was initiated for community-acquired pneumonia. Intravenous antibiotics were started and later switched to oral therapy after improvement in overall condition. The patient did not progress to severe disease; ICU admission was not required, and the course was managed on the general ward. Symptoms improved, and the patient was discharged home.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with dyspnea and fever. On admission, SpO2 was 85–88% on room air, and oxygen therapy was initiated. Chest CT showed infiltrates predominantly in the left lower lobe, and antibiotic therapy was started. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated and later transitioned to oral therapy after improvement in overall condition. Respiratory failure required intensive care unit management, and NPPV was provided for ventilatory support. After improvement, the patient was transferred to the general ward. Oxygen was discontinued after several days, and the patient remained stable on room air thereafter. The patient was transferred to another facility for continuation of rehabilitation.

HasNPPV.evidence: NPPV was provided for ventilatory support

HasICUCare.evidence: Respiratory failure required intensive care unit management

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with fever and dyspnea. On admission, SpO2 was 90–92% on room air, and oxygen therapy was initiated. Chest CT revealed an infiltrate in the right lower lobe, and treatment was started for community-acquired pneumonia. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated and later switched to oral therapy after improvement in overall condition. ICU management was not required, and treatment was continued on the general ward. The patient was weaned from oxygen and subsequently discharged. The clinical condition was stable, and the patient was discharged home.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted due to worsening cough and fatigue. On admission, SpO2 was 90–92% on room air, and oxygen therapy was initiated. Chest X-ray showed bilateral lower lung field infiltrates, and community-acquired pneumonia was diagnosed. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated and later transitioned to oral therapy after improvement in overall condition. Given comorbid diabetes mellitus, glycemic control was required and insulin therapy was introduced. The patient did not progress to severe disease; ICU admission was not required, and the course was managed on the general ward. Oxygen was discontinued after several days, and the patient remained stable on room air thereafter. Inflammatory markers improved, and the patient returned home.

[Hospital Course] The patient presented with fever, cough, and sputum production and was admitted. SpO2 on admission was 96% on room air, and oxygen therapy was not required. Chest CT revealed an infiltrate in the right lower lobe, and treatment was initiated for community-acquired pneumonia. Intravenous antibiotics were started and later switched to oral therapy after improvement in overall condition. ICU/HCU management was not required, and the patient improved with ward-based care. The clinical condition remained stable, and the patient was discharged home.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with fever and dyspnea. On admission, SpO2 was 88–90% on room air, and oxygen therapy was initiated. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated and later switched to oral therapy after improvement in overall condition. Chest imaging showed findings consistent with pneumonia; however, SpO2 on admission was 96% on room air, and respiratory status was stable. Oxygen therapy and ICU management were deemed unnecessary, and the patient was treated with antibiotics alone. The course was favorable, and the patient was discharged after a short hospitalization.

[Hospital Course] The patient developed fever and cough after choking during a meal and was admitted. On admission, SpO2 was 90–92% on room air, and oxygen was started via nasal cannula. Imaging showed lower-lobe–predominant infiltrates, and intravenous antibiotics were initiated for aspiration pneumonia. A swallowing evaluation was performed and diet consistency was adjusted. After improvement, antibiotics were switched to oral therapy; oxygen was weaned, and the patient was discharged home.

On admission, SpO2 was 86–88% on room air; oxygen therapy was initiated, and NPPV was started due to increased work of breathing. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia and required ICU-level management because of poor overall condition. After improvement, the patient was transferred to the general ward and, following swallowing evaluation, was transferred to another facility.

Chest imaging showed minimal evidence of pneumonia, and the condition was assessed as an acute exacerbation of COPD. Oxygen therapy was administered for hypoxemia, and treatment with inhaled bronchodilators and systemic corticosteroids was initiated. Respiratory status improved, oxygen was weaned, and the patient was discharged home.

HasOxygenTherapy.evidence: Oxygen therapy was administered for hypoxemia

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with worsening cough and dyspnea. On admission, SpO2 was 85–88% on room air, and oxygen therapy was initiated. The patient was treated for COPD exacerbation with bronchodilators and corticosteroids; however, hypercapnia was noted and NPPV was initiated. Respiratory management was provided under ICU-level care, and the patient was transferred after stabilization.

HasICUCare.evidence: Respiratory management was provided under ICU-level care

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with dyspnea and lower-extremity edema. Chest X-ray showed findings of congestion, and the patient was assessed as having acute decompensated heart failure. Oxygen therapy was administered for hypoxemia, and intravenous diuretics were started. Respiratory status improved with increased urine output, and therapy was transitioned to oral diuretics. ICU management was not required, and the patient was discharged home.

HasOxygenTherapy.evidence: Oxygen therapy was administered for hypoxemia

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was transported by ambulance for orthopnea and dyspnea. Pulmonary edema due to acute heart failure exacerbation was suspected. SpO2 was in the 80s on room air; oxygen therapy was initiated and NPPV was started. Intravenous diuretics were administered, and the patient was managed in the ICU until stabilized. After improvement, the patient was transferred to the general ward and then transferred to another facility for convalescent care.

HasICUCare.evidence: the patient was managed in the ICU until stabilized

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with fever and fatigue. Cough was mild and respiratory symptoms were not prominent. Urinalysis showed evidence of infection, and intravenous antibiotics and fluid resuscitation were initiated for a urinary tract infection. After defervescence and improvement in inflammatory markers, antibiotics were transitioned to oral therapy. The patient was clinically stable and discharged home.

HasAntibioticsIV.evidence: intravenous antibiotics and fluid resuscitation were initiated for a urinary tract infection

HasAntibioticsPO.evidence: antibiotics were transitioned to oral therapy

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with high fever and altered mental status. A urinary tract infection was suspected, and intravenous antibiotics and fluids were initiated. Hemodynamics were stable, but tachypnea and desaturation were noted, and supplemental oxygen was provided. After infection control, the overall condition improved, and the patient was transferred to another facility for ongoing rehabilitation.

HasAntibioticsIV.evidence: intravenous antibiotics and fluids were initiated

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with sore throat, fever, and cough. The presentation was mainly an upper respiratory tract infection with minimal evidence of pneumonia; however, dehydration and dyspnea were reported, and supplemental oxygen was provided briefly with SpO2 in the 90s. The patient improved with symptomatic treatment, oxygen was weaned, and ICU management was not required. The patient was discharged home.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with hemiparesis and diagnosed with cerebral infarction. After admission, swallowing function declined; swallowing evaluation and diet modification were performed to prevent aspiration. Respiratory symptoms were not prominent, and pneumonia treatment was not the primary focus. After acute-phase management, the patient was transferred to another facility for rehabilitation.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with cough, sputum production, and low-grade fever. Chest imaging did not clearly show pneumonia, and acute bronchitis was diagnosed. The patient improved with symptomatic treatment, including bronchodilators. Oxygen therapy and ICU management were not required, and the patient was discharged home.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with wheezing and dyspnea. Treatment for an asthma exacerbation was started with inhaled therapy and systemic corticosteroids. Supplemental oxygen was provided temporarily for desaturation. Chest imaging showed minimal evidence of pneumonia, and ICU management was not required. The patient improved and was discharged.

HasOxygenTherapy.evidence: Supplemental oxygen was provided temporarily for desaturation.

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with chest pain and diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction. Emergent PCI was performed and antiplatelet therapy was initiated. Respiratory symptoms were not the main issue; however, mild dyspnea was reported after the procedure, and supplemental oxygen was kept to a minimum with stable status. The clinical course was favorable, and the patient was discharged home.

HasOxygenTherapy.evidence: supplemental oxygen was kept to a minimum

Hospital_Course: [Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with vomiting, diarrhea, and fever. Marked dehydration was present, and treatment focused on intravenous fluids. Respiratory symptoms were not prominent; supplemental oxygen and antibiotics were not required. The overall condition improved, and the patient was discharged home.

[Hospital Course] The patient was admitted with high fever and hypotension. Sepsis was suspected, and intravenous antibiotics and fluid resuscitation were initiated. Due to tachypnea and desaturation, supplemental oxygen was provided and the patient was managed in the ICU. After infection control, hemodynamics improved, and the patient was transferred to a convalescent facility.

An acute exacerbation of interstitial pneumonia was suspected, and supplemental oxygen was initiated for hypoxemia. Corticosteroid therapy was administered; signs of infection were limited, and antibiotics were used as adjunctive therapy. ICU management was not required, and the patient was discharged home after improvement in respiratory status.

Supplemental oxygen was initiated for an acute exacerbation of interstitial pneumonia, and NPPV was started due to respiratory failure. The patient received ICU respiratory management and corticosteroid therapy. After improvement, the patient was transferred to the general ward and then transferred to another facility for continued convalescent care.

Intravenous antibiotics were started for aspiration pneumonia, and insulin therapy was introduced for glycemic management in the setting of diabetes mellitus. Swallowing evaluation was performed and diet consistency was adjusted. After improvement, antibiotics were transitioned to oral therapy; oxygen was weaned, and the patient was discharged.
